titleStmt.title: AY and NO, a Tale from Dublin; written in 1737.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: AT Dublin's high feast sat Primate and Dean,
Both dress'd like divines, with band and face clean.

Quoth Hugh of Armagh·Dr. Hugh Boulter, who was a commoner of Christ Church, Oxford, was chosen a demy of Magdalen College at the same election with Mr. Addison and Dr. Wilcox. He was invited to London by secretary Hedges in 1700, to whom he was chaplain; and obtained from the earl of Sunderland the parsonage of St. Olave, Southwark, and the arch-
deaconry of Surrey. He attended king George I. to Hanover in 1719, taught the English language to prince Frederick; and was promoted to the deanry of Christ Church and bishoprick of Bristol Oct. 20, the same year; and to the archbishoprick of Armagh, Aug. 21, 1724. The latter promotion he would have declined; but his judgement, moderation, and address, being thought necessary to quench the flame which Wood's ruinous project had occasioned, the king laid his commands on him, to which he reluctantly submitted. He made a visit to his native country in June 1742, and died in London the September following. His public charities in Ireland amounted to upwards of thirty thousand pounds.── When a young man, he joined with Ambrose Philips, who was afterwards his secretary, and others, in a Paper called “The Free-thinker,” since collected in three volumes. His “State Letters” have been lately published, in two volumes octavo., “The mob is grown bold,”

“Ay, ay,” quoth the Dean, “the cause is old gold·To remedy the scarcity of silver coin, the primate supported a scheme at the council-table, to bring gold and silver nearer to a par, by lowering that of the former; which was carried into execution. The populace, encouraged by some dealers in exchange, who were the principal losers, grew clamorous; but, experience evincing the utility of the project, the people soon recovered their senses, and he rose to the greatest height of popularity..”
“No, no,” quoth the Primate, “if causes we sift,
“This mischief arises from witty Dean Swift.”
The smart one replied, “There's no wit in the case;
“And nothing of that ever troubled your Grace.
“Though with your state-sieve your own notions you split,
“A Boulter by name is no bolter of wit.
“It is matter of weight, and a mere money-job;
“But the lower the coin, the higher the mob.
“Go tell your friend Bob and the other great folk,
“That sinking the coin is a dangerous joke.
“The Irish dear joys have enough common sense,
“To treat gold reduced like Wood's copper pence.
“It is pity a Prelate should die without law;
“But if I say the word── take care of Armagh!”
